24.14: And the young girl to whom I shall say, “Let down for me your cruse; I shall drink and she will say to me, ‘give drink to your camels also’, this is whom you have prepared for your Servant, Isaaq, and by this I shall know that you work favor and truth with my Master.”
24.15: And he had not yet finished speaking, and behold, Raphqa came out who was born to Bethuyl, son of Melka, the wife of Nakhor, the brother of Abraham, and a cruse was on her shoulder.
24.16: And the young girl was very beautiful in her appearance, a virgin whom a man had not known, and she came down to the well and filled her cruse and she came up.
24.17: And the Servant ran to meet her and he said to her, “Let me drink a little water from your cruse.”
24.18: And she said to him, “Drink, my Lord”, and she was quick, and she let down her cruse on her hands and gave him a drink.
24.19: And she finished giving him a drink and she said, “Also I shall fill your camels until they will be filled drinking.”
24.20: And she hurried and emptied her cruse in the trough, and she ran again to the well to fill up, and she filled all his camels.
24.21: And the man drank and he observed her and waited to know if LORD JEHOVAH had prospered his way or not.
24.22: And when the camels had finished drinking, the Servant took an earring of gold, its weight a shekel, and two bracelets for her hands, their weight of ten shekels of gold;
24.23: And he said to her, “Whose daughter are you? Show me if there is for us a place in your father's house to lodge.
24.24: And she said to him, “I am daughter of Bethuyel, son of Melka, whom she bore to Nakhor.”
24.25: And she said to him, “Also we have straw and much provender and a place to lodge.”
24.26: And the man knelt on the ground and he worshipped LORD JEHOVAH.
24.27: And said, “Blessed is LORD JEHOVAH, the God of my Lord Abraham, who did not deny my Lord his grace and his truth, but LORD JEHOVAH led me in the way of the house of the brother of my Lord, to take the daughter of the brother of my Lord for his son.”
24.28: And the girl ran and she showed these words to her father's household.
24.29: And Raphqa had a brother and his name was Laban, and Laban ran to the man outside at the well.
24.30: When he saw the earrings and bracelets on the hands of his sister, and when he heard the words of Raphqa his sister, when she said, “Thus the man said to me”, and he came to the man, and behold, he was standing with the camels by the well.
24.31: He said to him, “Come in, he who is blessed of LORD JEHOVAH. Why do you stand in the street and I have prepared the house and a place for the camels?”
24.32: And the man entered the house and he loosed the camels and cast straw and hay for the camels and water to wash his feet and the feet of the men who were with him.
24.33: And they placed food before them, and he said, “I shall not eat until I speak my words;” they were saying to him, “Speak.”
24.34: And the Servant said, “I am of Abraham.”
24.35: And LORD JEHOVAH has blessed my Master and he is very great and he has sheep and oxen and silver and gold and Servants and maids and female donkeys and camels and male donkeys.
24.36: And Sara the wife of my Lord bore a son to my Lord after she was old, and he gave to him everything that he has.
24.37: And my Lord made me swear and said to me, “Do not take a woman for my son from the daughters of the Canaanites, in whose land I dwell:
24.38: But go to the house of my father and to my family and take a woman for my son from there.”
24.39: And I said to my Lord, “And perhaps the woman will not desire to come with me?”
24.40: And my Lord said to me, “LORD JEHOVAH, before whom I serve, He will send his Angel with you and he will establish your road and take a woman for my son from my family and from the house of my father:
24.41: And then you will be clear from my oath when you go to my family, and if they do not give to you, you are free from my oath.”
24.42: And I have come today to the well and I said, “LORD JEHOVAH, God of my Master Abraham, if you have prepared my way upon which I have come:
24.43: Behold I am standing at a well of waters and a young woman goes out to fill up waters and I will say to her, ‘Let me drink a little water from your cruse’;
24.44: And she will say to me also, ‘You drink, also I shall fill your camels’, she is the woman that LORD JEHOVAH has prepared for the son of my Master.”
24.45: And I had not yet finished speaking in my heart and behold, Raphqa came out and the cruse was on her shoulder, and she came down to the spring and filled up, and I said to her, “Let me drink a little water from your cruse.”
24.46: And she hurried and let down her cruse from her and she said to me, “Drink, also I shall water your camels”, and I drank; she gave drink also to the camels.
24.47: And I asked and I said to her, “Whose daughter are you?” And she said, “I am the daughter of Bethuyel, son of Nakhor, to whom Melka had given birth”, and I put bracelets on her hands and earrings on her ears.
24.48: And I knelt and I worshipped LORD JEHOVAH and I blessed LORD JEHOVAH, the God of my Master, Abraham, who led me in the way of truth to the house of the brother of my Master, to take the daughter of the brother of my Lord for his son.
24.49: And now if you are practicing favor and truth with my Lord, show me, and otherwise show me, and I shall turn to the right or to the left.”
24.50: And Laban and Bethuyel answered and they said, “The word has proceeded from LORD JEHOVAH; we are not able to speak to you good or evil.
24.51: Behold, Raphqa is before you; take her and go and she shall be a wife to the son of your Master, just as LORD JEHOVAH said.”
24.52: And when the Servant of Abraham heard their words, he worshiped on the ground before LORD JEHOVAH.
24.53: And the Servant brought out vessels of gold and vessels of silver, and garments, and he gave them to Raphqa, and he gave gifts to her brother and to her mother.
24.54: And they ate and they drank, he and the men who were with him, and they lodged and arose at dawn, and he said to them, “Send me to my Master.”
24.55: And her brother and her mother said to him, “The girl will dwell with us a month of days and then she will go.”
24.56: He said to them, “Do not delay me, for LORD JEHOVAH has made my way ready; send me and I shall go on to my Master.”
24.57: And they said, “We will call the girl and we will ask from her mouth.”
24.58: And they called Raphqa and they said to her, are you going with this man?” and she said, “I am going.”
24.59: And they sent Raphqa their sister and her nurse and the Servant of Abraham and his men.
24.60: And they blessed Raphqa their sister and they said to her, “Our sister, you will be for a thousand and for ten thousands, and your seed will inherit the lands of its enemies.”
24.61: And Raphqa arose, and her young women, and sat down on camels, and she went on after the man, and the Servant took Raphqa and went on.
24.62: And Isaac was coming from Beer D'Khaya Khezan and he dwelt in the land of the south.
24.63: And Isaaq went out to walk in a field at evening time, and he lifted his eyes and he saw, and behold, camels were coming.
24.64: And Raphqa lifted her eyes and she saw Isaaq, and she bowed on the camel.
24.65: And she said to the Servant, “Who is this man coming in the field to meet us?”, and the Servant said, “He is my Master”, and she took the bridal veil and covered herself.
24.66: And the Servant related to Isaaq all the responses she had made.
24.67: And Isaaq brought her to the tent of Sara his mother, and he took Raphqa, and she was his wife, and he loved her and Isaaq was comforted after his mother had died.

25.1: And Abraham went on and he took a wife, and her name was Qentura.
25.2: And she bore to him Zimran and Yaqshan and Madan and Median and Ashbaq and Ashwakh.
25.3: And Yaqshan begot Sheba and Daran, and the sons of Daran were Ashudim and Latshim and Amim.
25.4: And the sons of Median: Epha and Khaphar and Khanuk and Abeeda and Eldaa; all of these are the sons of Qentura.
25.5: And Abraham gave everything that he had to Isaaq his son.
25.6: And to the children of the concubine of Abraham, Abraham gave gifts, and he sent them from the presence of Isaaq his son while he was living at first in the land of the East.
25.7: And these were the days of the years of the life of Abraham who lived a hundred and seventy and five years.
25.8: And Abraham became ill and died in a good old age; he was old and satisfied with his days and was gathered to his people.
25.9: And Isaaq and Ishmayl, his sons, buried him in the double cave in the field of Aphron, son of Tsakhar the Khythite, that is before Mamreh;
25.10: The field that Abraham bought from the sons of Khyth for an inheritance of the tomb; there Abraham was buried and Sara his wife.
25.11: And it was after Abraham was dead, God blessed Isaaq his son, and Isaaq sat down on the side of Beer d'KhayaKhezan “The well of Life saw me.”
25.12: And these are the generations of Ishmayl, son of Abraham, to whom Hagar the Egyptian, the Handmaid of Sara, had given birth by Abraham:
25.13: And these are the names of the sons of Ishmayl by their names to their generations: the first born of Ishmayl, Nebiuth and Qedar and Arbal and Mabsam,
25.15: And Khadar, Tayma and Netuur and Nephesh and Qedem:
25.16: These are the sons of Ishmayl, and these are their names in their habitations and in their sheepfolds, twelve Princes to their people.
25.17: And these are the years of the life of Ishmayl: a hundred and thirty and seven years, and he became ill and he died and was gathered to his people.
25.18: And they dwelt from Khaweela and unto Shuud that is before Egypt, which is in the entrance of Assyria; on the borders of all his brothers he had dwelt.
25.19: And these are the generations of Isaac son of Abraham: Abraham begot Isaaq:
25.20: And Isaaq was a son of forty years when he took Raphqa, the daughter of Bethuyel, the Aramaean, from Padan d'Aram, the sister of Laban the Aramaean, a wife for himself.
25.21: And Isaaq prayed before LORD JEHOVAH, because his wife was sterile, and LORD JEHOVAH answered him, and Raphqa his wife became pregnant.
25.22: And her children were crowded in her womb, and she said, “If it is like this, why am I living”? And she went to ask of LORD JEHOVAH.
25.23: And LORD JEHOVAH said to her: “Two peoples are in your womb, and two nations shall be separated from your womb, and one nation shall be stronger than the other nation, and the greater shall be subject to the lesser.”
25.24: And her days were fulfilled to give birth, and behold, twins were in her womb.
25.25: And one went out first, red and all ringlets of hair, and he called his name Esau.
25.26: And after him his brother went out, and his hand was holding on the heel of Esau, and he called his name Yaquuv, and Isaac was a son of sixty years when she gave birth to them.
25.27: And the boys grew, and Esau was a man knowing hunting, a man of the wilderness, and Yaquuv was a harmless man and dwelling in a tent.
25.28: And Isaaq loved Esau because he ate his game, and Raphqa loved Yaquuv.
25.29: And Yaquuv boiled stew, and behold, Esau his brother came from the field and he was famished:
25.30: And Esau said to Yaquuv, “Give me a taste of these red lentils, because I am famished”; for this, he called his name Adum.
25.31: Yaquuv said to him, “Sell to me today your firstborn inheritance.”
25.32: And Esau said in his heart, “Behold, I am going to die. Why is the inheritance going to me?”
25.33: Yaquuv said to him, “Swear to me today”, and he swore to him, and he sold his firstborn birthright to Yaquuv.
25.34: And Yaquuv gave to Esau bread and stew of lentils to eat, and he ate and drank, and he stood and went; and Esau despised concerning the firstborn inheritance.

26.1: And a famine was in the land, apart from the first famine that had occurred in the days of Abraham, and Isaaq went on to Abimelek, the King of the Philistines, to Gadar.
26.2: And LORD JEHOVAH appeared to him and said to him, “Do not go down to Egypt. Dwell in the land that I shall tell you:
26.3: Dwell in this land, and I shall be with you and I shall bless you, because to you and to your seed I shall give all these kingdoms, and I shall establish the oath that I swore to Abraham your father;
26.4: And I shall multiply your seed as the stars of Heaven, and I shall give to your seed all these lands, and all of the nations of Earth shall be blessed by your seed;
26.5: For the sake of Abraham, who heard my voice and kept my observances and my commandments and my covenants and my laws.”
26.6: And Isaaq settled down in Gadar:
26.7: And the men of the place asked him about his wife and he said, “She is my sister”, because he was afraid to say, “She is my wife”, lest the men of the place would kill him, because Raphqa was beautiful in her appearance.
26.8: And it was that when the days grew long to him there, Abimelek the King of the Philistines looked out from a window and he saw Isaaq dancing with Raphqa his wife.
26.9: And Abimelek called to Isaaq and said to him, “Behold, she is your wife; how were you saying ‘she is my sister?’” Isaaq said to him, “Because I said, ‘Lest I shall die because of her.’
26.10: Abimelek said to him, “What is this that you have done to us, after a little time, one of the people would have been lying down with your wife and you would have been bringing sin upon us!”
26.11: And Abimelek commanded all the people and said, “Whoever molests this man or his wife shall surely be killed.”
26.12: And Isaaq sowed in the land and he found in that year a hundredfold of barley and LORD JEHOVAH blessed him.
26.13: And the man became great and he kept on going until he was very great:
26.14: And he had possessions of sheep and possessions of oxen and great estate, and the Philistines were jealous of him.
26.15: And all the wells the workers of his father had dug in the days of Abraham his father, the Philistines polluted and filled them with dirt.
26.16: And Abimelek said to Isaaq, “Go from our presence because you have become much stronger than we are.”
26.17: And Isaaq went on from there and he dwelt in the valley of Gadar and settled down there.
26.18: And Isaaq returned and dug the wells of waters that the workers of his father had dug in the days of Abraham his father, and the Philistines polluted them after Abraham was dead, and he called them names according to the names that his father had called them.
26.19: And the workers of Isaac dug in the valley and they found there a well of living waters.
26.20: And the herdsmen of Gadar contended with the herdsmen of Isaac and they said, “The waters are ours”, and he called the name of the well Asqa, because they disputed with him.
26.21: And they dug another well and they contended also over it, and he called its name Satana.
26.22: And he departed from there and they dug another well, and they did not contend over it and he called its name Rekhbuuth, and said, “Now LORD JEHOVAH has enlarged us and has increased us in the earth.”
26.23: And he went up from there to Beersheba.
26.24: And LORD JEHOVAH was revealed unto him in that night and he said to him, “I AM the God of Abraham your father; do not fear, because I am with you and I shall bless you, and I shall increase your seed because of Abraham my Servant.”
26.25: And he built there an altar and he called on the Name of LORD JEHOVAH, and he pitched his tent there and the workers of Isaac dug a well there.
26.26: And Abimelek came to him from Gadar, and Akhzwath his friend, and Phikal the Leader of his army.
26.27: And Isaaq said to them, “Why have you come to me? You have hated me and sent me from your presence.”
26.28: And they said to him, “Observing, we see that LORD JEHOVAH has been with you and we were saying that there should be an oath between us and you, and we will make a covenant with you;
26.29: That you will not do evil to us, just as we have not harmed you, and just as we have done right to you, and we sent you in peace. You are now blessed of LORD JEHOVAH.”
26.30: And he made a feast for them and they ate and they drank.
26.31: And they arose at dawn and each man made an oath to his brother, and Isaaq sent them and they went from his presence in peace.
26.32: And so it was in that day and the Servants of Isaac came and they showed him about the matter of a well that they had dug and they said to him, “We have found water.”
26.33: And he called its name Seba, because of this he called the name of the city Beerseba until today.
26.34: And Esau was a son of forty years, and he took a woman Yehudith, daughter of Beeri the Khethite, and Besmath, daughter of Elwan the Khivite:
26.35: And they grieved the spirit of Isaac and of Raphqa.

27.1: And it was that when Isaaq was old and his eyes were too dull to see, he called Esau, his elder son, and said to him, “My son”, and he said, “Here I am.”
27.2: And Isaaq said to him, “Behold, I am old and I do not know the day that I die.
27.3: Now take your weapons your sword and your bow and arrows and go out to the country and hunt game
27.4: And make stew like I love and bring it to me; I shall eat so that my soul may bless you before I die.”
27.5: And Raphqa heard when Isaaq spoke to Esau his son, and Esau went on to the field to hunt game to bring.
27.6: And Raphqa said to Yaquuv her son, “Behold, I heard your father, saying to Esau your brother,
27.7: ‘Bring to me game and make stew for me and I shall eat and I shall bless you in the presence of LORD JEHOVAH before my death.’
27.8: Now my son, listen to my voice, whatever I command you.
27.9: Go to the flock and take for me from there two goats of the better goats, and I shall make them stew for your father as he loves:
27.10: And I shall bring it to your father and he will eat and he will bless you in the presence of LORD JEHOVAH before his death.
27.11: And Yaquuv said to Raphqa his mother, “Behold, Esau my brother is a hairy man and I am a smooth man:
27.12: It may be my father will feel me and I shall be in his eyes as a mocker and you bring against me a curse and not a blessing.”
27.13: And his mother said to him, “Let your curse be upon me, my son, only hear my voice and go get it for me.”
27.14: And he went on, he took and he brought it to his mother and his mother made stew just as his father loved.
27.15: And Raphqa took a choice garment of Esau her elder son that she had with her in the house and she clothed Yaquuv her younger son:
27.16: And she wrapped the skin of a kid of the goats on his hands and upon the smooth of his neck.
27.17: And she gave the stew and the bread that she had made to Yaquuv her son.
27.18: And he brought it to his father and said, “My father”, and he said, “Here I am”, and he said, “Who are you, my son?”
27.19: And Yaquuv said to his father, “I am your son, your first born, Esau. I have done as you said to me; arise, sit and eat of my game so your soul may bless me.”
27.20: And Isaaq said to his son, “What is this that you have found so quickly, my son?” And he said, “That which LORD JEHOVAH your God has prepared before me.”
27.21: And Isaaq said to Yaquuv, his son, “Come near; now I shall feel you my son, if you are my son Esau or not.”
27.22: And Yaquuv came to Isaaq his father and he felt him and he said, “The voice of Yaquuv and the feel of the hands of Esau.”
27.23: And he did not recognize him because his hands were like the hands of Esau his hairy brother, and he blessed him.
27.24: And he said “Is this you, my son Esau?” and he said, “I am.”
27.25: And he said to him, “Come to me; I shall eat of the game of my son, so my soul will bless you”, and he came to him and he ate and he brought wine to him and he drank.
27.26: And Isaaq his father said to him, “Come near and kiss me, my son.”
27.27: And he came near and he kissed him and he smelled the fragrance of his clothing and he blessed him and said, “See, the fragrance of my son is like the fragrance of a field that LORD JEHOVAH has blessed:
27.28: God will give to you from the dew of Heaven and from the fat of the Earth and an abundance of grain and of wine.
27.29: The nations shall serve you and the peoples shall bow down to you; be the head to your brethren and the children of your mother will bow to you; those cursing you are cursed and those blessing you are blessed.”
27.30: And when Isaaq had finished blessing Yaquuv and Yaquuv went out from the presence of Isaaq his father, behold, Esau his brother came from his hunting.
27.31: He also had made stew and brought it to his father and said to his father, “Let my father rise and let him eat of his son’s game, so that your soul may bless me.”
27.32: Isaaq his father said to him, “Who are you?” And he said, “I am your son, your firstborn, Esau.”
27.33: And his father sorrowed a great and very powerful sorrow and he said, “Who indeed is he that hunted game and he brought it to me and I ate of it all before you came? And I have blessed him, also he shall be blessed.”
27.34: And when Esau heard the words of his father, he wailed a great and very bitter wail and he said to his father, “Bless me also, even me, oh my father!”
27.35: His father said to him, “Your brother came in by treachery and he has taken your blessings.”
27.36: And Esau said, “Truly was his name called Yaquuv, who has betrayed me; behold, two times he took my birthright, and now, see, he has taken my blessing.” And Esau said to his father, “Do you not have a blessing left for me?”
27.37: Isaaq answered and said to Esau “Now I have made him the head to you, also I have given all of his brothers to him as Servants and with grain and with wine I have sustained him and therefore, what shall I do for you my son?”
27.38: And Esau said to his father, “You have one blessing, my father; bless me also, even me, my father!” And Esau lifted up his voice and wept.
27.39: Isaaq his father answered and said to him, “Behold, your dwelling shall be in the richness of the Earth and from dew of Heaven from above;
27.40: And you shall live by your sword and you shall serve your brother, and if you are converted, his yoke will pass from your neck.”
27.41: And Esau looked with evil on Yaquuv for the blessings with which his father blessed him, and Esau said in his heart, “Let the days of my father’s place of mourning come and I shall kill Yaquuv my brother.”
27.42: And the words of Esau her elder son were told to Raphqa and she sent and she called Yaquuv her younger son and she said to him, “See, Esau your brother is threatening you to kill you.
27.43: Now my son, hear my voice and arise, go to Laban my brother to Kharan;
27.44: And stay there a few days until the anger of your brother will be calmed down
27.45: And until the anger of your brother will pass over you, and he will forget that which you have done to him, and I shall send and bring you from there, lest I am also bereaved of you two in one day.”
27.46: And Raphqa said to Isaaq, “I have been grieved myself in my life by the presence of the daughters of Khyth; if Yaquuv takes a woman from the daughters of Khyth like these daughters of the land, why should life go on for me?”

28.1: And Isaaq called Yaquuv and blessed him and he commanded him and said to him, “Do not take a woman from the daughters of Canaan.
28.2: Arise, go to Padan d'Aram to the house of Bethuyel, the father of your mother, and take for yourself from there a woman from the daughters of Laban, the brother of your mother.
28.3: And God Almighty will bless you and will increase you and multiply you, and you shall be a multitude of peoples;
28.4: And he will give to you the blessing of Abraham, to you and to your seed with you, and he shall cause you to inherit the land of your habitation that God gave to Abraham.”
28.5: And Isaaq sent Yaquuv and he went on to Paran d'Aram to Laban, son of Bethuyel the Aramaean, the brother of Raphqa, the mother of Yaquuv and of Esau.
28.6: And Esau saw that Isaaq blessed Yaquuv his brother and sent him to Paran d'Aram to take to himself from there a wife when he blessed him and commanded him and said to him, “Do not take a woman from the daughters of Canaan”;
28.7: And Yaquuv listened to his father and to his mother and he went on to Padan d'Aram;
28.8: And Esau saw that the daughters of Canaan were evil in the eyes of Isaaq his father;
28.9: And Esau went on to Ishmayl and he took Besmath, daughter of Ishmayl, son of Abraham, the sister of Nebiuth, in addition to his wives, as a wife for himself.
28.10: And Yaquuv went out from Beersheba to go to Kharan.
28.11: And he arrived in the place and he spent the night there because the sun had set, and he took from the stones of the place and laid his pillow and slept in that place.
28.12: And he saw in a dream, and behold, a staircase set up on the earth, and the top met Heaven, and behold, the Angels of God were going up and coming down on it.
28.13: And behold LORD JEHOVAH was standing above it, and LORD JEHOVAH said: “I AM the God of Abraham your father, and the God of Isaac; the land upon which you lie I shall give to you and to your seed;
28.14: And your seed will be as the dust of the Earth and you will multiply to the East and to the West and to the North and to the South, and in you and in your seed all the generations of the Earth will be blessed.
28.15: And see, I am with you and I shall keep you wherever you will go, and I shall return you to this land and I shall not leave you until I shall do whatever I have said to you.”
28.16: And Yaquuv was awakened from his sleep and he said, “Truly, LORD JEHOVAH is in this place and I not have known.”
28.17: And Yaquuv feared a great fear and said, “How awesome is this place today! This is nothing but the house of God and this is the gate of Heaven!”
28.18: And Yaquuv arose at dawn and he took the stone that he had set as his pillow and he made it a monument and he poured oil on its top.
28.19: And Yaquuv called the name of that place Bayth Eil, however, Luz was the name of that region from the first.
28.20: And Yaquuv vowed a vow and said, “If God will be with me and he will keep me in this way in which I go, and he will give to me bread to eat and clothes to wear,
28.21: And I shall return in peace to the house of my father, LORD JEHOVAH shall be God to me,
28.22: And this stone that I have made a monument will be the house of God, and a tenth of all that you give to me I shall give as a tithe to you.”

29.1: And Yaquuv lifted up his feet and he went on to the land of the children of the East.
29.2: And he saw, and behold, a well in a field, and there were three flocks of sheep lying by it, because the flock was drinking at the well, and a great stone was on the mouth of the well.
29.3: And all the flocks assembled there and they rolled the stone from the mouth of the well and they give drink to the sheep and return the stone to the mouth of the well in its place.
29.4: Yaquuv said to them, “My brothers, from where are you?” They were saying to him, “We are from Kharan.”
29.5: He said to them, “Do you know Laban, son of Nakhor?” They said to him, “We know.”
29.6: He said to them, “Is he well?” They said to him, “He is well, and look, Rakhyl his daughter is coming with the sheep.”
29.7: Yaquuv said to them, “See, daylight still remains; it is not time to gather the cattle; water the sheep and go feed them.”
29.8: They were saying to him, “We cannot until all of the flocks assemble, and they roll the stone from the mouth of the well and we give drink to the sheep.”
29.9: And while he was speaking with them, Rakhyl came with the sheep of her father because she was a shepherdess.
29.10: And when Yaquuv saw Rakhyl, daughter of Laban, the brother of his mother, and the sheep of Laban, the brother of his mother, Yaquuv came and rolled the stone from the mouth of the well, and he gave drink to the flock of Laban, the brother of his mother.
29.11: And Yaquuv kissed Rakhyl, and he lifted his voice and wept.
29.12: And Yaquuv told Rakhyl that he was the brother of her father and that he was son of Raphqa, and she ran and she told her father.
29.13: And when Laban heard the report of Yaquuv, son of his sister, he ran to meet him and embraced him and he kissed him and brought him to his house and he related to Laban all these words.
29.14: Laban said to him, “Truly you are my bones and my flesh”, and he stayed with him a month of days.
29.15: And Laban said to Yaquuv, “Truly my brother, are you to work for me without charge? Tell me, what are your wages?”
29.16: And Laban had two daughters; the name of the elder was Leah and the name of the younger, Rakhyl.
29.17: And the eyes of Leah were tender and Rakhyl was beautiful in her appearance and her face was beautiful.
29.18: And Yaquuv loved Rakhyl and he said, “I shall work for you seven years for Rakhyl, your younger daughter.”
29.19: Laban said to him, “Better that I give her to you than that I give her to another man. Stay with me.”
29.20: And Yaquuv worked for Rakhyl seven years, and they were in his eyes as a few days, because he loved her.
29.21: And Yaquuv said to Laban, “Give me my wife, because the days are ended, and I shall go into her.”
29.22: And Laban gathered all the men of the place and made a banquet.
29.23: And when it was evening, he brought Leah his daughter and brought her to him, and he came in unto her.
29.24: And Laban gave Zelpha, his Handmaid, to Leah his daughter as a Handmaid.
29.25: And when it was dawn and he saw that she was Leah, he said to Laban, “What is this that you have done to me? Look, I worked with you for Rakhyl. Why have you deceived me?”
29.26: And Laban said to Yaquuv, “It is not done in this way in our place, to give the younger before the elder.
29.27: Complete the wedding of this one and I shall give her to you also for the service that you will serve again with me for seven more years.
29.28: And Yaquuv did so and completed her wedding and he gave Rakhyl his daughter to him as a wife.
29.29: And Laban gave to his daughter Rakhyl, Balha, his Handmaid, for a Maidservant.
29.30: And he went in also unto Rakhyl and he loved Rakhyl also more than Leah, and he worked with him again seven more years.
29.31: And LORD JEHOVAH saw that Leah was despised and he opened her womb, and Rakhyl was a sterile woman.
29.32: And Leah became pregnant and she bore a son and she called his name Rubyl, and she said “Because God saw my oppression; now my husband will love me.”
29.33: And she was pregnant again and she bore a son and she said, “Because LORD JEHOVAH heard that I am hated, he gave me also this one”, and she called his name Shemon.
29.34: And she was pregnant again and she bore a son and she said, “This time my husband will cleave to me, because I have given birth to three sons for him; because of this, she called his name Levi.
29.35: And she became pregnant again and she bore a son and she said, “This time I shall praise LORD JEHOVAH”, because of this, she called his name Yehuda, and she ceased from child bearing.

30.1: And Rakhyl saw that she was not child bearing to Yaquuv, and she envied her sister and she said to Yaquuv, “Give me children, otherwise I am dead!”
30.2: And the anger of Yaquuv was provoked because of Rakhyl and he said to her, “Am I in the place of God, he who withholds from you the fruit of the womb?”
30.3: And she said to him, “Here is my maid Balha; go in upon her and she shall bear on my knees and I shall be comforted, even I, by her.”
30.4: And she gave to him Balha her Handmaid as a wife and he went in unto her.
30.5: And Balha became pregnant and she bore to Yaquuv a son.
30.6: And Rakhyl said, “God has judged me, also he has heard my voice and he gave to me a son”; because of this, she called his name Dan.
30.7: And Balha the Handmaid of Rakhyl became pregnant again and she bore another son to Yaquuv.
30.8: And Rakhyl said, “I begged of LORD JEHOVAH and I prayed with my sister and also I have found”, and she called his name Naphtali.
30.9: And Leah saw that she ceased from child bearing and she brought Zelpha her Handmaid and she gave her as a wife to Yaquuv.
30.10: And Zelpha the Handmaid of Leah bore to Yaquuv a son.
30.11: And Leah said, “My fortune has come!”, and she called his name Gad.
30.12: And Zelpha the Handmaid of Leah bore a second son to Yaquuv.
30.13: And Leah said, “The daughters are singing my praise to me”, and she called his name Ashir.
30.14: And Rubyl went on in the days of the harvest of wheat and he found mandrakes in a field and he brought them to Leah his mother, and Rakhyl said to Leah, “Give me some of your son’s mandrakes.”
30.15: And Leah said to her, “Is it not enough for you that you have taken my husband, but also that you will take the mandrakes of my son?” And Rakhyl said, “Because of this he will sleep with you this night for the mandrakes of your son.”
30.16: And Yaquuv came in from the field in the evening and Leah came out to meet him and she said, “Come into me because assuredly I have hired you with the mandrakes of my son”; and he lay with her that night.
30.17: And God heard Leah and she became pregnant and she bore to Yaquuv a fifth son.
30.18: And Leah said, “God gave my reward for I have given my Maid to my husband”, and she called his name, Issakar.
30.19: And Leah became pregnant again and she bore a sixth son to Yaquuv.
30.20: And Leah said “God has endowed me a good dowry; this time my husband will cleave to me, because I have given birth to six sons by him”, and she called his name Zabalaun.
30.21: And after that, she gave birth to a daughter and she called her name, Dinah.
30.22: And God remembered Rakhyl, and God heard her and opened her womb.
30.23: And she was pregnant and she bore a son and she said, “God has taken away my reproach”:
30.24: And she called his name Yoseph, and she said, “God will add to me another son.”
30.25: And when Rakhyl gave birth to Yoseph, Yaquuv said to Laban, “Send me; I shall go to my place and to my land.
30.26: Give to me my wives and the children of your service for them, and I shall go, because you know the work that I have done for you.”
30.27: And Laban said to Yaquuv, “If I have found favor in your eyes, I have proven that LORD JEHOVAH blessed me because of you.”
30.28: And he said, “Appoint your wages for me, and I shall give.”
30.29: Yaquuv said to him, “You know the service with which I have served you and that your possessions are with me.
30.30: Because you had little before me, and it has increased much, and LORD JEHOVAH has blessed you for my sake, and now what shall I do, even I, for my house?”
30.31: Laban said to him, “What shall I give to you?” Yaquuv said to him, “You will give me nothing, if you make the response to me that I shall tell you. I shall return, I shall tend and I shall keep your sheep.
30.32: I shall pass among all your sheep today and I shall separate for myself from there every white spotted forehead lamb and spotted, and every lamb that is speckled in white and spotted, and the white spotted forehead among the goats, and it will be my reward.
30.33: And you will testify before me of my innocence, as today, then tomorrow, when you will bring on my reward before you; everyone that will not be white spotted forehead and spotted among the goats and speckled in white will have been stolen by me.”
30.34: Laban said to him, “Yes, it shall be according to your word.”
30.35: And he separated on that day the white spotted forehead he goats, and spotted and all white spotted forehead female goats, and spotted females and everything that was white among them, and everyone that was speckled in white, and he gave them into the hand of his children.
30.36: And he made a three days’ journey between him and Laban, and Yaquuv fed the flock of Laban which remained.
30.37: And Yaquuv took to him fresh white rods of almond and of the plane tree and he stripped them of the white bark and they became whiter, white in the rods.
30.38: And he fastened the rods that he stripped while waters were running at the drinking place where the flocks came to drink next to the flock; and they conceived when they came to drink.
30.39: And the flock conceived lambs before the rods and the flock gave birth to white spotted forehead and spotted.
30.40: And Yaquuv separated and he put before the flock white spotted forehead and spotted lambs and every one speckled among the flock of Laban, and he made a flock for himself alone and he did mingle them in the flock of Laban.
30.41: And every time that the flock conceived early, Yaquuv laid down a rod before the flock by the running water when they conceived among the rods.
30.42: And among the late breeders of the flock he was not laying it down, and the late breeders were for Laban and the early for Yaquuv.
30.43: And the man became very rich and he had many flocks and Servants, and Handmaids and female donkeys, and camels and male donkeys.

31.1: And Yaquuv heard the words of the children of Laban who said, “Yaquuv took everything that our father had and whatever our father possessed, all of this property.”
31.2: And Yaquuv saw the face of Laban which was not with him as it had been yesterday and as the day before.
31.3: And LORD JEHOVAH said to Yaquuv: “Return to the land of your fathers and to your family, and I shall be with you.”
31.4: And Yaquuv sent and he called Rakhyl and Leah to the field with his flock,
31.5: And he said to them, “I saw the face of your father, that it is not with me like yesterday and like the day before, and the God of my father has been with me.
31.6: And you know that with all my power I have served your father.
31.7: And your father has deceived me and has changed my wages ten times, and God did not allow him to do evil to me.
31.8: If in this way he would say, ‘the white spotted shall be your reward’, all the flocks would bear young white spotted, and if he would say ‘the spotted shall be your reward’, all the flocks would bear young spotted.
31.9: And God separated from the possessions of your father and he gave them to me.
31.10: And at the season of breeding flocks I lifted my eyes and I saw in a dream, and behold, goats mounting upon the flock, white spotted and spotted and speckled.
31.11: And the Angel of God said to me in a dream, ‘Yaquuv’, and I said, ‘Here I am.’
31.12: And he said to me, ‘Lift up your eyes and see all the goats mounting on the flock with white spotted foreheads, and spotted and speckled, because I have seen everything that Laban has done to you.
31.13: I AM the God of BaythEil, which you anointed for me there as a monument, and you vowed to me there a vow. Now arise, go out from this land and return to the land of your generations.”
31.14: And Rakhyl and Leah answered and they were saying, “Again we have no part or inheritance in the house of our father.
31.15: Behold we are considered as strangers to him, because we are sold and he consumes our money.
31.16: Because God has separated all wealth from our father; it is ours and our children's, and now all that LORD JEHOVAH has said to you, do.”
31.17: And Yaquuv stood and lifted his children and his wives onto camels;
31.18: And he took all his livestock and all his possessions that he acquired in Padan d'Aram to come to Isaaq his father, to the land of Canaan.
31.19: And Laban went to shear his flock and Rakhyl stole the images of her father.
31.20: And Yaquuv deceived the heart of Laban the Aramaean because he did not tell him that he was leaving.
31.21: And he fled, he and all whom he had, and he arose and he passed through the river and set his face toward Mount Gilead.
31.22: And it was told to Laban on the third day that Yaquuv fled from him.
31.23: And he took his brothers with him and pursued after him a seven days’ journey and he overtook him in the Mount of Gilead.
31.24: And God came upon Laban the Aramaean in a dream of the night and he said to him, “Beware that you do not speak with Yaquuv of good or for evil.”
31.25: And Laban overtook Yaquuv, and Yaquuv pitched his tent in the mountain, and Laban led his brothers in the mountain of Gilead.
31.26: And Laban said to Yaquuv, “What have I done to you that you have deceived my heart, and you have taken my daughters like captives by the sword?
31.27: Why did you hide to flee and steal away from me, and you did not tell me? I would have sent you in joy and with music and with harps and with tambourines.
31.28: And you have not let me kiss my sons and my daughters; now you have done wrong in the thing that you have done.
31.29: It had come into my hands to do harm to you, and the God of your father said to me in the evening, ‘Beware, lest you speak with Yaquuv of good or for evil.’
31.30: And now you are going because you truly long for the house of your father. Why have you stolen my gods?”
31.31: And Yaquuv answered and said to Laban, “Because I was afraid, and I said, lest you will take your daughters from me.
31.32: The one with whom your gods are found shall not live. Make known what I have that is yours before our brethren and take it for yourself”; and Yaquuv did not know that Rakhyl had stolen them.
31.33: And Laban entered the tent of Yaquuv and the tent of Leah and the second tent of the Maidservants and he did not find them, and he went out from the tent of Leah and entered the tent of Rakhyl.
31.34: And Rakhyl had taken the images and she set them in the saddle canopy of the camel and she sat upon them, and Laban searched the whole tent and he did not find them.
31.35: And Rakhyl said to her father, “Let it not be displeasing in the eyes of my Lord that I cannot rise from before you, because the custom of women is upon me”, and he searched and he did not find the images.
31.36: And it displeased Yaquuv, and he argued with Laban and Yaquuv answered and said to Laban, “What is my crime, and what is my fault that you have chased after me?
31.37: See, you have searched all my vessels. What have you found from all the vessels of your house? Put it here before my brothers and your brothers, and they will convict between both.
31.38: Behold I have been with you twenty years; your ewes and your shegoats are not barren and the rams of your flocks I have not consumed.
31.39: And that which was torn I have not brought to you; I was keeping it that you would seek it from my hands; I was with that which was stolen by day and what was stolen in the night.
31.40: So I was; by day the heat consumed me and the cold in the night drove sleep from my eyes.
31.41: Behold I had twenty years in your house. I worked for you fourteen years for your two daughters and six years for your flocks and you changed my pay ten times.
31.42: And if the God of My father, the God of Abraham and the awe of Isaac had not stood up for me, now you would have sent me with nothing; and God saw my toil and the labor of my hands and rebuked you in the evening.
31.43: And Laban answered and said to Yaquuv, “The daughters of my daughters, and the sons of my sons, and the flocks of my flocks, and everything that you see is mine. What shall I do for these my daughters today, or for their sons whom they have borne?
31.44: And now, come; let us establish a covenant, I and you, and it will be a witness between me and you.
31.45: And Yaquuv took a stone and raised it as a monument.
31.46: And Yaquuv told his brothers to gather stones, and they took stones and they made a mound, and they ate there on the mound.
31.47: And Laban called it Yagra d’Sahadutha“Mound of the Testimony”, and Yaquuv called it Galeed.
31.48: And Laban said, “This mound is a witness between me and you today”; because of this, he called its name Galeed
31.49: And the Watchtower, for he said, “LORD JEHOVAH will watch between me and you, because we are parting, each man from his brother.
31.50: If you despise my daughters and if you take wives beside my daughters, there is no man with us; see that God is witness between me and you.”
31.51: And Laban said to Yaquuv, “See this mound and see this monument that I set up between me and you.
31.52: This heap testifies and this monument is a witness that I shall not cross over this heap to you, also you will not pass over this heap and this monument for evil.
31.53: The God of Abraham, the God of Nakhor, the God of our fathers will judge between us”; and Yaquuv swore in the awe of his father Isaaq.
31.54: And Yaquuv sacrificed a sacrifice in the mountain and he called his brothers to eat bread, and they ate bread and they spent the night in the mountain.
31.55: And Laban arose at dawn and kissed his sons and his daughters, and he blessed them, and Laban returned and he went on to his place.

32.1: Also Yaquuv went his way and the Angels of God met with him.
32.2: And Yaquuv said, when he saw them, “This is the camp of God”, and he called the name of that country Makhanim.
32.3: And Yaquuv sent Messengers before him to Esau his brother, to the land of Sair, to the plain of Adum.
32.4: And he commanded them and said to them, “Thus you will say to my Lord Esau: thus said your Servant Yaquuv: ‘I have dwelt and I stayed with Laban until today
32.5: And I have bulls and donkeys and flocks and Servants and Maidservants and I sent to show my Lord to find mercy in your eyes.’”
32.6: And the Messengers returned to Yaquuv and they said to him: “We went on to Esau your brother, and now also he comes to meet you and four hundred men with him.”
32.7: And Yaquuv was afraid and it was very distressing to him, and he divided the people that were with him, and the flocks and oxen and camels into two camps;
32.8: And Yaquuv said, “If Esau my brother will come upon one camp and he will destroy it, the camp that remains escapes.”
32.9: And he prayed and said, “God of my father, Abraham, the God of my father, Isaaq, LORD JEHOVAH, who said to me, ‘Return to the land of your fathers and to your families, and I shall do good to you’:
32.10: I am unworthy of all your kindness and of all the truth that you have performed with your Servant, because with my staff I crossed this Jordan, and now I am with two camps.
32.11: Save me from the hands of Esau my brother, because I am afraid of him, lest he will come and strike mother with her children.
32.12: And you have said, ‘To do good, I shall do good to you, and I shall make your seed as the sand of the sea that is innumerable by its multitude.’”
32.13: And he spent the night there that night and he took a gift from what was in his hand for Esau his brother;
32.14: Two hundred she goats and twenty he goats, two hundred ewes and twenty rams.
32.15: Thirty nursing camels and their young, forty cows and ten bulls, twenty donkeys and ten colts.
32.16: And he gave into the hand of his Servants a fold each by itself, and said to his Servants, “Pass before me and make a space between each fold and the next fold.”
32.17: And he commanded the leader and said to him, “When Esau my brother meets you and he asks you and says to you, ‘Who are you and where are you going, and whose are these that are before you?’
32.18: Say to him, ‘Your Servant Yaquuv’s gifts that he sends to my Lord Esau, and behold, he is also coming after us.’”
32.19: And he commanded the second, also the third, and also all who were going after a fold saying, “According to this answer you will say to Esau whenever you have found him
32.20: And say to him, ‘Behold also your Servant Yaquuv is behind us, because he said, I shall appease his anger with the offerings that go before me, and after I shall see his face, perhaps he will accept my face.”
32.21: And the offering passed over before him and he lodged in the camp that night.
32.22: And he arose in the night and he took his two wives and his two handmaids and his eleven children and made them pass into the wilderness of Yabaq.
32.23: And he led them and made them cross over the river and made everyone whom he had to cross over.
32.24: And Yaquuv remained alone, and a man fought with him until the rising of dawn.
32.25: And he saw that he did not match his strength, and he touched his hip, and the hip of Yaquuv was dislocated as he fought with him.
32.26: And he said to him, “Let me go, because dawn is rising”, and he said, “I shall not send you unless you have blessed me.”
32.27: And he said to him, “What is your name?”, and he said, “Yaquuv”.
32.28: And he said to him, “Your name will not be called, Yaquuv again, but Israel, because you are proven with Angel and with Man, and you have found power.”
32.29: And Yaquuv asked him and said, “Show me your name”; he said to him, “Why do you ask about my name?”, and he blessed him there.
32.30: And Yaquuv called the name of that country, Penuyel, because, “I saw an Angel face to face and my life is saved.”
32.31: And the sun was setting to him when he passed through Penuyel and he was halting from his hip.
32.32: Because of this, the children of Israel do not eat the meat of the sinew of the hip, that is in the hip of the thigh until today, because he touched the hip of the thigh of Yaquuv, the sinew of the hip.

33.1: And Yaquuv lifted up his eyes and he saw, and look, Esau came and four hundred men with him, and he divided the children with Leah and with Rakhyl and with the two Handmaids.
33.2: And he made the Maidservants and their children first and Leah and her children after them and Rakhyl and Yoseph last.
33.3: And he passed before them and he bowed on the Earth seven times until he approached his brother.
33.4: And Esau ran to meet him and embraced him and he fell on his neck and he kissed him and wept.
33.5: And Esau lifted his eyes and he saw the women and the boys and said, “From where do you have these?”, and he said, “The children are what God gave your Servant.”
33.6: And those Maidservants came near and their children and they bowed.
33.7: And Leah came near also, and her sons, and they bowed, and after that Rakhyl and Yoseph approached also, and they bowed.
33.8: And Esau said, “From where do you have all this camp that met me?”, and Yaquuv said to him, “Because I have found favor in the eyes of my Lord.”
33.9: And Esau said to him, “I have and I have much my brother; keep yours.”
33.10: Yaquuv said to him, “If I have found favor in your eyes, take my offering from my hands, because now I see your face as the appearance of the face of an Angel, and you are pleased with me.
33.11: Take my blessing that is with you because God was kind to me and because I have everything”, and he urged him and he accepted.
33.12: Esau said to him, “We will pick up and we will go, and I shall go before you.”
33.13: Yaquuv said to him, “My Lord, know that the boys are young and the flocks and oxen are nursing with me and if I drive them one day, the entire flock will die.
33.14: Let my Lord pass before his Servant and I shall walk slowly the leg of the household that is before me and the leg of the children until I come to my Lord in Sair.
33.15: Esau said, “I shall leave for you some of the people who are with me”, and Yaquuv said, “Why has it happened for me to find mercy in the eyes of my Lord?”
33.16: And Esau returned that day on the road to Sair.
33.17: And Yaquuv picked up for Sukuth and built for himself a house, and for his cattle he made shelters; because of this he called the name of that country Sukuth.
33.18: And Yaquuv came to Shaleem, the city of Shekeem, which is in the land of Canaan, when he came from Padan d'Aram, and he camped opposite the city.
33.19: And he bought a part of the field from the children of Khamor, the father of Shekeem, with a hundred ewes, and he pitched the tent there.
33.20: And he raised up there an altar and he called it Eil Alaha d’Eesreel The Defender God of Israel.

34.1: And Dinah came out, daughter of Leah, who was begotten by Yaquuv, to see the daughters of the place.
34.2: And Shekeem saw her, son of Khamor, Khwaya the Khivite, Prince of the land, and he took her and lay with her and disgraced her.
34.3: And his soul went forth after Dinah the daughter of Yaquuv, and he loved the girl and was filled in his heart with the girl.
34.4: And Shekeem said to Khamor his father, “Take for me this girl as a wife.”
34.5: And Yaquuv heard that he had defiled Dinah his daughter, and his sons were with the livestock in the field, and Yaquuv was silent until they came.
34.6: And Khamor the father of Shekeem went out to Yaquuv to speak with him.
34.7: And the sons of Yaquuv came from the field and when they heard, it grieved them to a man, and it was very evil to them because they had done an abomination in Israel and abused the daughter of Yaquuv, and such is not done.
34.8: And Khamor spoke with them and said to them, “Shekeem my son has desired the soul of your daughter; give her to him as a wife.
34.9: And be married with us; give your daughter to us and take our daughters to yourselves.
34.10: And dwell with us and behold, the land is before you; dwell and trade and inherit in it.”
34.11: And Shekeem said to her father and to her brothers, “Let me find mercy in your eyes, and everything that you will say to me I shall give.
34.12: Multiply against me a great dowry and gifts and I shall give just as you say to me, and give this girl to me as a wife.”
34.13: And the sons of Yaquuv answered Shecheem and Khamor his father, and they spoke to him with treachery, because they had defiled Dinah their sister.
34.14: And they said, “We cannot do this thing to give our sister to a man that has foreskin, because that is a reproach to us:
34.15: However in this we will consent to you, if it is that you would be like us and you will circumcise every male just as we are circumcised
34.16: We will give to you our daughters and your daughters we will take to us, and we will dwell with you and we will be one people.
34.17: And if you do not listen to us to circumcise, we will take our daughters and we will go.”
34.18: And their words were pleasing in the eyes of Khamor and in the eyes of Shekeem his son.
34.19: And the boy did not delay to do the deed, because he was delighted with the daughter of Yaquuv and he was more honorable than all the household of his father.
34.20: And Khamor came, and Shekeem his son, to the gate of their city and they spoke with the men of their city and they said to them,
34.21: “These men are in agreement with us; they will dwell in the land and they will trade in it, and now the land expanse round about is before them. We will take their daughters to ourselves as wives and we will give our daughters to them.
34.22: However in this the men are persuaded by us that they will dwell with us and will be one people, whenever we circumcise every male just as those men are circumcised.
34.23: Their wealth and their possessions and all their cattle behold, they are ours, however we will consent to them and they will dwell with us.”
34.24: And everyone exiting the gate of his city heard from Shekeem and they circumcised every male, all that went out the gate of his city.
34.25: And it was in the third day, when their sufferings were severe, the two sons of Yaquuv, Shemon and Levi, the brothers of Dinah, took each man his sword and they entered against the city in silence and murdered every male.
34.26: And they murdered Khamor and Shekeem his son with the mouth of the sword, and they took Dinah from the house of Shekeem and they went out.
34.27: And the sons of Yaquuv entered upon the slain and they plundered the town because they had defiled Dinah their sister.
34.28: And their sheep and their oxen and their donkeys that were in the town and in the field, they took away,
34.29: And they seized all their meat and all their wealth and their wives, when they seized all that was in the town.
34.30: And Yaquuv said to Shemon and to Levi, “You have done me damage for you have done evil to me among the inhabitants of the land, among the Canaanites and among the Perizites, and I am small in number, and they will assemble against me and strike me, and I shall be destroyed and my house.”
34.31: And they said, “Our sister was treated like a whore!”

35.1: And LORD JEHOVAH said to Yaquuv: “Arise, come up to BaythEil and dwell there, and make an altar there to God who was revealed unto you when you fled from before Esau your brother.”
35.2: And Yaquuv said to the sons of his house and to every one of his people, “Send out the foreign gods that are among you and be purified and change your garments,
35.3: And arise, go up to BaythEil, and I shall make there an altar to God who answered me in the day of my suffering, and he was with me in the way that I have gone.”
35.4: And they gave to Yaquuv all their foreign gods that were in their hands and the earrings in their ears, and Yaquuv buried them under the Oak that was with Shekeem.
35.5: And they picked up, and the fear of God was on the towns that were in their surroundings, and they did not pursue after Yaquuv and after his sons.
35.6: And Yaquuv came to Luz that was in the land of Canaan, which is BaythEil, he and all the people with him.
35.7: And he built there an altar and he called that place BaythEil, because there God was revealed unto him when he had fled from before Esau his brother.
35.8: And Debora, the Nurse of Raphqa, died, and she was buried under BaythEil, under the Oak, and he called its name Betemtha dav'Katha.
35.9: And God was revealed again to Yaquuv when he came from Padan d'Aram and he blessed him.
35.10: And God said to him, “Your name shall not be called Yaquuv again, but your name shall be Israel”, and he called his name Israel.
35.11: And God said to him, “I AM Almighty God; increase and multiply as a people, and a multitude of nations shall be from you, and Kings will go out from your loins;
35.12: And the land that I swore to Abraham and to Isaac, to you I shall give it, and to your seed after you I shall give the land.”
35.13: And God was lifted up from him in the place where he spoke with him.
35.14: And Yaquuv raised up a monument in the place where he spoke with him, a monument of stone, and he poured upon it a drink offering and he poured upon it oil.
35.15: And Yaquuv called the name of the region where God spoke with him there, BaythEil.
35.16: And he picked up from BaythEil and traveled again about a journey of a Pharsakh of the land, to enter Ephrath, and Rakhyl gave birth, and she went into hard labor when she was giving birth.
35.17: And it was that when she was in labor, the midwife said to her, “Do not fear, because this son also is yours.”
35.18: And it was that when her soul was going out and she was dying, she called his name Bar Kabi – (son of my sorrow), and his father called him Benyamin.
35.19: And Rakhyl died and she was buried in the way of Ephrath, this is Bayth Lekhem.
35.20: And Yaquuv raised up a monument on the grave of Rakhyl, this is the monument of the grave of Rakhyl until today.
35.21: And Israel picked up and he pitched his tent from there to Magdala of Gadar.
35.22: And it was that when Israel had dwelt in that land, Rubil went and he lay with Balha the Concubine of his father, and Israel heard; and there were twelve sons of Yaquuv,
35.23: The sons of Leah: the first born of Yaquuv, Rubil and Shemon and Levi and Yehuda and Issakar and Zabalaun:
35.24: And the sons of Rakhyl; Yoseph and Benyamin:
35.25: And the sons of Balha, the Handmaid of Rakhyl: Dan and Naphtali
35.26: And the sons of Zelpha, the Handmaid of Leah: Gad and Ashir: these are the sons of Yaquuv that were born to him in Padan d'Aram.
35.27: And Yaquuv came to Isaaq his father to Mamreh Qorith Ganabra, that is Khebron that is in the land of Canaan, where Abraham dwelt and Isaac.
35.28: And the days of Isaac were a hundred and eighty years.
35.29: And Isaaq became ill and he died and he was gathered to his people; he was old and his days were full, and they buried Esau and Yaquuv his sons in the tomb that Abraham his father had bought.

36.1: And these are the generations of Esau; Esau is Adum.
36.2: Esau took his wives from the daughters of Canaan; Ada daughter of Alun the Khethite and Ahulibama daughter of Ana, son of Tsebaun the Khivite;
36.3: And Besmath, daughter of Ishmayl, was the sister of Nebiuth.
36.4: And Ada bore Eliphaz to Esau, and Besmath gave birth to Rawaeil;
36.5: And Ahulibama gave birth to Yawish and Yalan and Qurakh; these are the children of Esau who were born to him in the land of Canaan.
36.6: And Esau took his wives and his children and his daughters and every soul of his house and all his cattle and all his possessions that he possessed in the land of Canaan, and he went on to the land of Seir from before Yaquuv his brother.
36.7: Because their cattle were too abundant to dwell together and the land that they inhabited was not sufficient to contain them, because of their cattle.
36.8: And Esau dwelt in the mountains of Seir; Esau is Adum.
36.9: And these are the generations of Esau, the father of the Adumites in the mountain of Seir,
36.10: And these are the names of the children of Esau: Ruil, son of Besmath, the wife of Esau, Eliphaz, son of Ada, the wife of Esau.
36.11: And the sons of Eliphaz were, Tayman and Umar and Tsephu and Gatham and Qanaz.
36.12: And Tamna was a concubine to Eliphaz, son of Esau, and she bore Amaleeq to Eliphaz; these are the children of Ada the wife of Esau.
36.13: And these are the sons of Ruil: Nakhath and Zarakh and Shama and Maza; these are the sons of Besmath the wife of Esau.
36.14: And these are the sons of Ahlibama, the daughter of Ana, who was son of Tsabown the wife of Esau, and she bore to Esau, Yaush and Yalan and Qurakh.
36.15: And these are the Princes of the sons of Esau, the sons of Eliphaz, the firstborn of Esau: Prince Tayman, Prince Umar, Prince Tsephu, Prince Qanaz.
36.16: Prince Gatham, Prince Qurakh, Prince Amaleeq; these are the Princes of Eliphaz in the land of Adum; these are the sons of Ada.
36.17: And these are the sons of Ruil, son of Esau: Prince Nakhath, Prince Zarakh, Prince Shama, Prince Maza; these are the Princes of Ruil in the land of Adum; these are the sons of Besmath, the wife of Esau.
36.18: And these are the sons of Ahlibama, the wife of Esau: Prince Yaush, Prince Yalan, Prince Qorakh; these are the sons of Ahlibama, daughter of Ana, the wife of Esau.
36.19: These are the sons of Esau and these are the Princes of Esau; he is Adum.
36.20: And these are the sons of Seir, the Khorites, dwellers of the land: Lutan and Shubal and Tsebun and Ana,
36.21: And Deeshun and Atsar and Deeshan; these are the Princes of Khorites, sons of Seir in the land of Adum.
36.22: And there were the sons of Lutan: Khori and Humam and the sister of Lutan, Tamna.
36.23: And these are the sons of Shubal: Ulan and Mankhath and Ubal and Shaphar and Uyam.
36.24: And these are the sons of Tsabown: Ana, and Ana is the Ana who found for himself waters in the wilderness when he was feeding the donkeys of Tsabown, his father.
36.25: And these are sons of Ana: Dishun, Ahlibama.
36.26: And these are sons of Dishun: Khamran and Ashban and Yathran and Kran.
36.27: And these are sons of Atsar: Kalhan and Zawan and Aqan.
36.28: And these are sons of Dishan: Uts and Aran.
36.29: And these are the Princes of Khorites: Prince Lutan, Prince Shubal, Prince Tsabown, Prince Ana.
36.30: Prince Dishun, Prince Atsar, Prince Dishan; these are the Princes of the Khorites to the Princes in the land of Seir.
36.31: And these are the Kings that reigned in the land of Adum before a King would reign over the children of Israel.
36.32: Bela reigned in Adum, son of Beor, and the name of the city, Dayhab.
36.33: And Bela died and Yubab reigned after him, son of Yarakh of Butsar.
36.34: And Yubab died and Kheshum reigned after him from the land of Timna.
36.35: And Kheshum died and Hadad reigned after him, son of Badad who killed Midianites in the fields of Muab, and the name of the city was Gweeth.
36.36: And Hadad died and Samla reigned after him from Maserqa.
36.37: And Samla died and Shawal reigned after him from Rekhbuth the river.
36.38: And Shawal died and Belkhnan, son of Abakur, reigned after him.
36.39: And Belkhnan, son of Abakur, died, and Hadad reigned after him and the name of his city was Pau, and the name of his wife, Mahtbayel, daughter of Matreed, son of Mizahab.
36.40: And these are the names of the Princes of Esau by their families, by their generations, by their names: Prince Tamna, Prince Anwa, and Prince Yathith.
36.41: Prince Ahlibama, Prince Eela, Prince Pinun,
36.42: Prince Qanz, Prince Tayman, Prince Mabtsar,
36.43: Prince Magdeel, Prince Giram, these are the Princes of the Adumites among their dwellings in the land of their inheritance; this is Esau the father of the Adumites.

37.1: And Yaquuv dwelt in the land of the dwelling of his father in the land of Canaan.
37.2: And these are the generations of Yaquuv: Yoseph, son of seventeen years, was shepherding a flock with his brothers, and he was Prince with the sons of Zelpha and with the sons of Balha, wives of his father, and Yoseph brought their evil report to their father.
37.3: And Israel had loved Yoseph more than all his sons because he was a son of old age to him, and he made for him a coat of long sleeves.
37.4: And his brothers saw that their father had loved him more than all of them, and they hated him and they were not able to speak peace with him.
37.5: And Yoseph dreamed a dream and he told it to his brothers and they hated him more.
37.6: And he said to them, “Hear this dream that I have dreamed:
37.7: Behold we were binding sheaves in the field and behold, my sheaf stood up and was erect, and behold your sheaves surrounded and bowed down to my sheaf.”
37.8: And his brothers said to him, “Do you truly reign over us, or being authorized, do you have authority with us?” And they hated him more due to his dream and due to his statement.
37.9: And he dreamed again another dream, and he related it to his brothers and said to them, “Look, again I have dreamed a dream, and behold, the sun and the moon and eleven stars were bowing down to me.”
37.10: And he related it to his father and to his brothers, and his father rebuked him and said to him, “What is this dream that you have dreamed? Truly, will we come, I and your mother and your brothers, to worship you on the ground?”
37.11: And his brothers were jealous of him, and his father was keeping the statement.
37.12: And the brothers of Yoseph went to shepherd the flock of their father in Shekim.
37.13: And Israel said to Yoseph, “Behold, your brothers are shepherding in Shekim; come, I shall send you to them”, and he said to him, “Here I am.”
37.14: And his father said to him, “Go, see the welfare of your brothers and the welfare of the sheep and bring me a report”, and Yaquuv sent him from the valley of Khebroun and he came to Shecheem.
37.15: And a man found him as he wandered in a field, and that man asked him and said to him, “What are you looking for?”
37.16: And he said, “I am looking for my brothers; show me where they are shepherding.”
37.17: The man said to him, “They took them from here and I heard that they said, ‘Let us go to Dawthan’ and Yoseph went on after his brothers and he found them in Dawthan.
37.18: And they saw him from a distance, and before he came to them, they were scheming against him to kill him.
37.19: And they said, each man to his brother, “Behold that dreamer comes dreaming.
37.20: Come, let us kill him and we will throw him into one of the pits and we will say, ‘A dangerous beast ate him’, and we will see what there is to his dream.”
37.21: And Rubyl heard, and he saved him from their hands and said to them, “We will not kill a soul.”
37.22: And Rubyl said to them, “You shall not shed blood. Throw him into this pit in the wilderness and do not stretch a hand against him”, so that he would save him from their hands and return him to his father.
37.23: And when Yoseph came to his brothers, they stripped him of the coat of long sleeves that he was wearing;
37.24: And they took him and they threw him into the pit, and the pit was empty and there was no water in it.
37.25: And they sat to eat bread and lifted up their eyes and they saw, and behold, a caravan of Arabia was coming from Gilead, and their camels were bearing balm and balsam and terebinth berries, and were going to carry them to Egypt.
37.26: And Yehuda his brother said, “What profit is there that we kill our brother and conceal his blood?
37.27: Come, let us sell him to the Arabs, and our hand will not be on him, because he is our brother and our flesh”, and his brothers listened to him.
37.28: And Midianite men, traders, passed and they dragged and carried Yoseph from the pit and they sold Yoseph to the Arabs for twenty silver coins, and they brought him to Egypt.
37.29: And Rubyl returned to the pit, and behold, Yoseph was not in it, and he ripped his clothes.
37.30: And he returned to his brothers and said to them, “Where is the boy? Where shall I go?”
37.31: And they took the coat of Yoseph and they killed a kid of the goats and they dipped the coat in its blood;
37.32: And they sent the coat of long sleeves and they brought it to their father and they said, “We found this; see if this is your son's coat or not.”
37.33: And he knew it and said, “It is the coat of my son. A dangerous animal has eaten him; it overcame and destroyed Yoseph my son.”
37.34: And Yaquuv ripped his clothes and was binding sackcloth around his waist, and he grieved for his son for many days.
37.35: And all his sons stood and all his daughters were comforting him, and he did not want to be comforted, and he said, “I shall descend to my son, as I wail, to Sheol”, and his father wept for him.
37.36: And the Midianites sold him into Egypt, to Putiphar the Chief Eunuch, the Guard of Pharaoh.

38.1: And it occurred at that time, Yehuda came down from the presence of his brothers and he departed to an Arlemite man, and his name was Khira.
38.2: And Yehuda saw there the daughter of a Canaanite man, and her name was Shua, and he took her and he went into her.
38.3: And she conceived and she bore to him a son, and he called his name Eyr.
38.4: And she conceived again and she bore a son, and he called his name Unan.
38.5: And she again bore a son, and he called his name Shela, and she ceased when she bore him.
38.6: And Yehuda took a woman for Eyr, his firstborn, and her name was Tamar.
38.7: And Eyr, the firstborn of Yehuda, was evil before LORD JEHOVAH, and LORD JEHOVAH put him to death.
38.8: And Yehuda said to Unan his son, “Go in unto the wife of your brother and do the part of a brother, and raise up seed to your brother.”
38.9: And Unan knew that the seed was not his, and when he entered on the wife of his brother he destroyed it on the ground, so that he would not raise up seed to his brother.
38.10: And what he did was evil before LORD JEHOVAH, and he put him to death, even him.
38.11: And Yehuda said to Tamar his daughter in law, “Remain in widowhood in your father's house until Shela my son grows, because he said, “Lest he should die also as his brothers”, and Tamar went and she dwelt in her father's house.
38.12: And days multiplied and the daughter of Shua, the wife of Yehuda, died, and Yehuda was comforted and he came up to the shearers of his flock, he and Khira his friend, the Arlemite, to Tamnath.
38.13: And they told Tamar and they said to her, “Behold, your father in law went up to Tamnath to shear his flock”,
38.14: And she put away the clothes of her widowhood from her, and she was covered with a veil and she was adorned, and she sat in the crossing of the roads, which is on the road of Tamnath, because she saw that Shela had grown and she had not been given to him.
38.15: And Yehuda saw and he considered her as a harlot because her face was covered.
38.16: And he turned aside to her on the road and he said to her, “Come, I shall come into you”, because he did not know that she was his daughter in law, and she said to him, “What will you give when you come into me?”
38.17: And he said, “I shall send a kid of the goats from the flock”, and she said, “If you give to me a pledge until you send it.”
38.18: And he said, “What pledge shall I give to you?”, and she said, “Your ring and your robe and your staff that is in your hand”, and he gave them to her, and he went into her and she conceived from him.
38.19: And she arose and she went and she put away the veil from her and she put on the clothes of her widowhood.
38.20: And Yehuda sent the kid of goats by his friend, the Arlemite, to take the pledge from the hands of the woman, and he did not find her.
38.21: And he asked the men of the place and said, “Where is the harlot who dwelt at the parting of the roads?”, and they said “There is no harlot here.”
38.22: And he returned to Yehuda and said, “I have not found her, also the men of the place were saying, “There is no harlot here.”
38.23: And Yehuda said, “She may take it, lest I be a laughing stock; behold, I have sent this kid and you have not found her.”
38.24: And it was after three months and it was told Yehuda, and they said to him, “Tamar your daughter in law has committed fornication, and behold, she is pregnant by fornication”, and Yehuda said, “Bring her out and she will burn.”
38.25: And when they brought her out, she sent to her father in law: “By the man to whom these things belong I am pregnant.” And she said, “See whose is the ring and the robe and staffthese things.”
38.26: And Yehuda knew and said, “She is innocent more than I, because of this, I did not give her to Shala my son”, and he did not have sexual relations with her again.
38.27: And it was the time of her delivery, and behold twins were in her womb.
38.28: And it was that when she delivered, he gave his hand and the midwife took a thread of scarlet and she tied it on his hand and she said, “This one will come forth first.”
38.29: And when he returned his hand, his brother came out and she said, “How a breach is breached upon you!” And she called his name Pharets.
38.30: And after that, his brother came out, on whose hand was the thread of scarlet, and she called his name Zarakh.

39.1: And the Midianites took Yoseph down to Egypt, and Putiphar the Eunuch, High Guard of Pharaoh, an Egyptian man, bought him from the hand of the Arabs who brought him down there.
39.2: And LORD JEHOVAH was with Yoseph and he was a prosperous man in the house of his lord the Egyptian.
39.3: And his lord saw that LORD JEHOVAH was with him and LORD JEHOVAH prospered everything that he did with his hands.
39.4: And Yoseph found favor in his eyes and he served him and he authorized him over his house and everything that he had he gave into his hands.
39.5: And it was from the time that he authorized him over his house and over everything that he had, LORD JEHOVAH blessed the house of the Egyptian because of Yoseph, and the blessing of LORD JEHOVAH was in everything that he had in the house and in the field.
39.6: And he left everything that he had in the hand of Yoseph, and he did not know anything that he had with him but the bread that he was eating. And Yoseph was handsome in his appearance and his face was attractive.
39.7: And it was after these matters, the wife of his lord set her eyes on Yoseph and she said to him, “Lie with me.”
39.8: And he did not want to, and he said to the wife of his lord, “Behold, my Lord does not know what is with me in his house, and everything that he has, he has authorized into my hands;
39.9: And there is none greater in this house than I, and not he has spared me anything but you, for you are his wife, and how shall I do this great evil and sin against God?”
39.10: And as she was speaking to him every day and he was not listening to her to lie with her and to be with her.
39.11: It was on one of the days, and Yoseph entered the house to do work, and there was no man of the men of the house there in the house.
39.12: And she caught him by his garment, and she said to him, “Lie with me”, and he left his garment in her hands, and escaping, he went out to the street.
39.13: And it was that when she saw that he left his garment in her hands and fled to the street.
39.14: She called the men of her house and she said to them, “See that he brought to us the Hebrew Servant to mock at us; he came in against me to lie with me and I cried out in a loud voice
39.15: And when he heard that I lifted up my voice and I cried out, he left his garment with me and fled; he went out to the street.”
39.16: And she laid aside his garment with her until his lord came into the house.
39.17: And she said to him, “According to these words the Hebrew Servant, whom you brought to us, came in against me to mock at us:
39.18: And when I lifted my voice and I cried out, he left his garment in my hands and fled; he went out to the street.”
39.19: And when his lord heard the words of his wife that she had told him: “According to these words your Servant did to me”, his anger was inflamed.
39.20: And his lord took him and threw him into prison where the prisoners of the King were bound, and he was there in the prison.
39.21: And LORD JEHOVAH was with Yoseph and cast favor over him, and he gave him affection in the eyes of the Chief of the prison.
39.22: And the Chief of prisoners delivered into the hand of Yoseph all the prisoners that were in the prison, and everything that they were doing there; he was the Bondsman.
39.23: And the Chief of the prisoners did not see anything in his hand, because LORD JEHOVAH was with him, and LORD JEHOVAH prospered everything that he was doing.

40.1: And it was after these events, the Chief of Drink of the King of Egypt and the Chief Baker sinned against their Lord, the King of Egypt.
40.2: And Pharaoh was angry against his two Eunuchs, against the Chief of Drink and against the Chief Baker.
40.3: And he cast them into the prison in the house of the Chief of the Guard, in the place where Yoseph was bound.
40.4: And the Chief of the Guard authorized Yoseph over them and he attended to them and they were some days in the house of prisoners.
40.5: And they dreamed a dream, both men his dream in the night, each man according to the interpretation of his dream, the Butler and the Baker of the King of Egypt, who were imprisoned in the house of prisoners.
40.6: And Yoseph went into them at dawn, and he saw them and behold, they were sad.
40.7: And he asked the Eunuchs of Pharaoh who were with him in imprisonment in the house of his lord and said to them, “Why are your faces sad today?”
40.8: And they said to him, “We dreamed a dream and there is no interpreter for it.” Yoseph said to them, “Behold, interpretations are of God; relate them to me.”
40.9: And the Chief of Drink related his dream to Yoseph, and he said to him, “In my dream, behold, a vine was before me
40.10: And in the vine were three branches, and when it made fruit, its leaves sprang up and its clusters ripened and there were grapes:
40.11: And the cup of Pharaoh was in my hand and I took grapes and I squeezed them into the cup of Pharaoh and I gave the cup to the hand of Pharaoh.”
40.12: Yoseph said to him, “This is the interpretation of your dream: three branches are three days:
40.13: After three days Pharaoh will be reminded of you and will restore you to your position, and you shall give the cup to Pharaoh in his hand, according to the former custom when you were Cupbearer to him.
40.14: But remember me being with you when it will be well with you, and do a favor and righteousness for me and remember me before Pharaoh and take me out of this prison
40.15: Because truly I am stolen from the land of the Hebrews, also I have done nothing here that they should cast me into a pit.”
40.16: And the Chief Baker saw that he interpreted well and said to Yoseph, “Also I am in my dream and behold, three baskets of white flour on my head:
